title: 115_hr5139
content: The Act may be cited as the "Hire Our Heroes to Protect Our Schools Act of 2018". According to 2016 data from the U.S. Department of Education, only 24% of elementary schools and 42% of high schools have school resource officers. The lack of officers is often due to financial constraints or a shortage of trained personnel. Retired law enforcement officers and veterans are well-equipped to handle school shooting situations and can serve as school resource officers. Many officers and veterans retire in their early fifties, still with years of service ahead. Placing retired police officers and veterans in schools as resource officers can enhance school security immediately. Officers and veterans often retire in their early fifties, with years of valuable service left to offer. Congress believes school systems should hire retired police officers and veterans as school resource officers. Additionally, there is a grant program for school security. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to provide evidence-based training and technical assistance for violence prevention in schools, including the use of metal detectors and other technologies. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include the placement of metal detectors and other deterrent measures in schools, along with assigning additional school resource officers, prioritizing veterans and retired law enforcement officers. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include training for preventing student violence, anonymous reporting, and the placement of metal detectors in schools. Additional school resource officers will be prioritized, including veterans and retired law enforcement officers. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include anonymous reporting systems for school violence threats, subgrants for implementing grants, and technology for expedited notification of law enforcement during emergencies. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to include various changes such as increasing the percentage of funding, updating terminology to mental health professionals, and making adjustments to specific sections like striking certain phrases and inserting new ones. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to increase funding from $30,000,000 to $100,000,000 and update the time frame from 2001 through 2009 to 2019 through 2024.
